subject: RE: [junit] The right amount of testing !?
msgSnippet: I have gone back and forth on the issue of throwing away tests. This week, I m comfortable with the idea. If the test were so important, I d remember it. Maybe
messageBody:
I have gone back and forth on the issue of throwing away tests. This week, I'm comfortable with the idea. If the test were so important, I'd remember it. Maybe when I change the implementation from trivial to nontrivial, the nontrivial implementation is radically different and I need different tests. The old tests make me feel too confident for no reason, so I throw them away.

Take care.

>So said Robert Brown on 4/24/2003 --------------------
>I agree with the trivial to nontrivial add tests, but if a test has been
>written I wouldn't throw it away.
>
>Robert Brown
>Sinex Aviation Technologies
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
>Sent: Thursday, April 24, 2003 3:42 PM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: RE: [junit] The right amount of testing !?
>
>
>>So said Robert Brown on 4/24/2003 --------------------
>>In my opinion, you should test every public method of a class. The
>>reason I have for this is that even though you know that the method
>>turns around and calls another method that is tested somewhere else,
>>that may not always be the case, and you don't know that the call is
>>coded correctly either, or that the underlying class/method hasn't been
>>changed to return something that is unexpected.
><snip />
>
>If a programmer changes the implementation from trivial to nontrivial,
>add some tests. If a programmer change the implementation from
>nontrivial to trivial, remove some tests. That may seem wasteful, but in
>my opinion, testing trivial code is more wasteful over time.
>
>Take care.
